Clocker: an open source macOS menubar app to plan and organize through timezones

Backstory of collaborating with the creator of open source macOS app to rebuild it from ground-up.

Posted Nov 22, 2018

So it all started with an email to Abhishek Banthia (creator and developer of Clocker) praising the app and asking if he has any plans to improve the design and experience of the app. Luckily he had some plans for a design overhaul and some cool new features.

So I started off with the goal of
‚Ä¢ Rebuild the visual language of the app
‚Ä¢ Add couple of new features in
‚Ä¢ Learn as much as possible on macOS app design patterns

Clocker screenshot on both light mode and dark mode

Calendar at a glance

New calendar feature

One of the most requested feature was the ability to see calendar at a glance. This is a big addition and it‚Äôll have ripple effects on other parts of the app, so we took careful consideration on how to implement the feature and its interactions. Our goal here was to keep it simple while providing the necessary information.

With this addition, Clocker will become an all in one tool to plan and organize your schedule through multiple timezones.

Preferences panel

Figma prototype of new preferences panel

Exisiting preferences panel was not using the system default pattern, which resulted in inconsistent experience across other apps users use every day. We restructured the information architecture of the preferences and designed it from scratch to match the system default pattern.

App icon

The all new design needed a new good looking app icon to match. After couple of iterations, following is the final version of new app icon that we decided on.

New Clocker app icon

We found few ways to illustrate the well known features as well as new upcoming features on app icon. More than one ‚Äúseconds‚Äù needle indicate the multi time zone feature and mini dots on background layer inidicate the upcoming calendar feature. This was a way for us to give a little bit of meaning and liveliness to the app icon.

As a designer who never worked on any macOS apps, this was a way for me to learn and execute macOS app design and interactions. The lack of Figma resources for macOS app design compared to iPhone and iPad is really surprising, so I decided to open source the designs as a way for me to give back to the community.

New design and features are not implemented yet but I suggest downloading the current version of Clocker on App Store. This will be a life saver when you work with remote teams on multiple timezones.

Go back home
